columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked  to determine if there is an arbitrage opportunity and the six-month forward rate to prevent abritrage.

## a.

We are asked to determine if there is an arbitrage opportunity.

**Arbitrage opportunities** are opportunities for *risk-free profits.* To determine if there is an arbitrage opportunity, we need to determine the *forward rate* using the formula of interest rate parity.
**Interest Rate Parity** states that difference of the interest rate of two countries is *the same* as the percentage difference between the the forward exchange rate and the spot exchange rate.

The formula of the interest rate parity is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times{\text{[1+($R_{FC}$}-{\text{$R_{US}$}}})]^t\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$F_{t}$ =  forward exchange rate for settlement at a given time 

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S.

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country

$S_{0}$ = Spot Exchange Rate

We are given the following data
- The spot rate on the Norwegian krone is Kr 8.39.
- The forward rate on the Norwegian krone is Kr 8.48.
- The annual risk-free rate in the United States is 3.8 percent.
- The the annual risk-free rate in Norway is 5.7 percent.

Applying the formula on Step 6:
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{180}$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times{\text{[1+($R_{FC}$}-{\text{$R_{US}$}}})]^{6/12}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{[1+(0.057}-{\text{0.038}}})]^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{(1+0.019}})^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{(1.019}})^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{1.0095}\\
&=\boxed{\text{Kr 8.47}}
\end{aligned}$$

The six-month forward exchange rate using the formula of interest parity gives **Kr 8.47**. Since it is less than the given forward rate of Kr 8.48, **an arbitrage opportunity exist here**. You can get more Norwegian Krone after six-months using the current forward rate.
Since there is an arbitrage opportunity, we will now determine how to exploit it.

Next, we will convert back the U.S dollar into Norwegian Krone using the forward rate of Kr 8.48.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Value in Kr} &= \text{Value in \$}\times{\text{Forward  Rate }}\\
&= \text{\$ 0.1214}\times{\text{8.48}}\\
&=\boxed{\text{Kr 1.0295}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Recall that the investment of Kr 1 will have a value of **Kr 1.0277** after six months. However, if we convert the investment of Kr 1 into dollars first, we will have a value of **Kr 1.0295**. We will have **Kr 0.0018 gain** if we convert it into dollars first.

As a conclusion, **an arbitrage opportunity exist**. To exploit it, we need to use the **different rates in adjusting the investment** to determine which will give us more gain even if both are risk-free investments.

## b.

We are asked to determine the six-month forward rate to prevent the arbitrage.

To determine how to prevent arbitrage, the six month forward rate to be used must be **less than** the current forward rate. We have already determined which forward rate is less than the current forward rate using the concept of interest rate parity.
**Interest Rate Parity** states that difference of the interest rate of two countries is *the same* as the percentage difference between the the forward exchange rate and the spot exchange rate.

Applying the formula in Step 20:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{180}$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times{\text{[1+($R_{FC}$}-{\text{$R_{US}$}}})]^{6/12}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{[1+(0.057}-{\text{0.038}}})]^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{(1+0.019}})^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{\text{(1.019}})^{1/2}\\[10pt]
 &=\text{Kr 8.39}\times{1.0095}\\
&=\boxed{\text{Kr 8.47}}
\end{aligned}$$
As a conclusion, to prevent arbitrage, the forward rate must be **Kr 8.47.**

To sum it all up, **there is an arbitrage opportunity** and to exploit it, we need to make **use of the exchange rates** to determine which will give us more profit. To prevent arbitrage, the forward rate must be **Kr 8.47.**
